p: Honey is a sweet, viscous food substance made by honey bees and some related insects ( Crane, 1990). Bees produce honey from the sugary secretions of plants (floral nectar) or secretions of other insects (such as honeydew), by regurgitation, enzymatic activity, and water evaporation. Bees store honey in wax structures called honeycombs ( Crane, 1990). The variety of honey produced by honey bees (the genus Apis) is the best-known, due to its worldwide commercial production and human consumption ( Al-kafaween et al., 2020). Honey is collected from wild bee colonies, or hives of domesticated bees, a practice known as beekeeping or apiculture. Honey gets its sweetness from the monosaccharides: fructose and glucose, and has about the same relative sweetness as sucrose (table sugar) ( NHB, 2012). The antimicrobial activity of honey against microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa has been reported in many scientific literatures ( Carter et al., 2016).
